text: former emergency a health care worker in
Dallas test positive for the killer
virus the news Americans have been
fearing the first possible transmission
of Ebola in America the deadly virus
which has claimed thousands of lives in
Africa has now spread within the u.s. a
worker at this hospital
in Dallas Texas has tested positive for
Ebola after reporting a low-grade fever
on Friday night she'd been treating this
man Thomas Eric Duncan who died last
week after contracting the virus in
Liberia measures had been put in place
to contain the virus but officials admit
things went wrong we don't know what
occurred in the care of the index
patient the original patient in Dallas
but at some point there was a breach in
protocol and that breach in protocol
resulted in this infection now the race
is on to stop it from spreading further
authorities have disinfected the woman's
apartment police are now guarding it and
others in the building have also been
contacted ebolas now claimed more than
4,000 lives in West Africa for these
workers in Sierra Leone burying the
victims has become a grim but daily task
concerns remain high in Europe after a
Spanish nurse contracted the disease
Teresa Romero had been treating Ebola
patients in a Madrid Hospital here in
America passengers from West Africa will
now be screened for the virus travelers
to the countries five largest airports
including New York's JFK will have their
temperatures taken and be made to answer
questions it is what it whatever you can
do to prevent something drastic is what
it many inconvenience I don't see why
there'd be any issues at all with that
I'd rather
then be safe at least our borders be
safe some in America say banning
travelers from West Africa is the only
way to contain Ebola for now people here
are asking what more can be done to
prevent the deadly virus from spreading
on US soil
Rajini Weiden Arden BBC News Washington
